reviews.review: The culmination of heroes we were all waiting for. And as expected with most Marvel films we're carried along the story with light hearted comedy and a thoughtfully driven villain till the thrilling cliff hanger that left me wanting answers and more.
Watching this movie can be compared to eating caramel popcorn when the bucket of popcorn ends, you are already tired of caramel.
just because they can, doesn't mean they should. a little plot would be nice next time.

Perhaps studio's are just trying to milk as much money from comic book movie goers by churning out movie after movie after movie. Hardly a month goes by without another hitting the big screen. Whilst visually these movies are great what they do lack is adequate comprehensible screenplay. Infinity War is one that just seems to amble on despite a week storyline. Messy from the start and never really amounts to much at all. It's a movie that thinks it is bigger than it is.

Absolute, utter perfection for a comic book movie. A culmination 10 years in the making and delivers in terms of comedy, drama, action, and consequences. A must see for any Marvel fan or if you like any of Marvelâ€™s previous 18 movies.
I didn't think I would like having so many characters in a movie, but it works for this one.
Obviously a setup for a second infinity war, but well done. Thor shines with his new "hammer" and I like how they managed to balance multiple heroes.

Infinity War is a solid, quite satisfying addition to the MCU that isn't quite as good as it could've been, but is still emotional and a great teaser for what will be the final film for this era of the franchise. It has more in common with Age of Ultron than say, Civil War, in the sense that it feels over-stuffed and a little heavy-handed, but unlike the former, it manages to push the characters and stories into interesting new directions. Thanos is probably the best villain the MCU has ever had (Loki is the other contender, though he's now pretty much a good guy...or is he?). One could complain that the main Avengers like Captain America take too much of a backseat to the other characters like the Guardians, but I imagine we'll see more of him in the next film. It's also impressive when you step back and realize how far these characters have come since their debuts, when their battles seemed much smaller in scale, more grounded and less apocalyptic. Bigger isn't always better, but Disney/Marvel deserve credit for crafting a long, complicated web and making it a blast for the audience. As usual, take note, DC. This isn't even the best Avengers movie, and it's still more exciting and emotionally resonant than Justice League and Batman vs. Superman combined.
perfect balance of fun and superhero
